She operates a farm where she grows crops. She also has a grinding mill where she grinds maize to sell. Her biggest business challenge is a lack of funds to buy pumps for irrigation. 

This is Judith's second loan with SMEP Deposit Taking Microfinance. Her previous loan, for 100,000 Kenyan shillings, was repaid successfully. She will use this loan, for 50,000 KES, to buy a water pump, water pipes and other accessories for irrigating her farm. 

In the future, she hopes that she will maximize the productivity of the farm through irrigation.

loans.use: to buy a water pump, water pipes and other accessories for irrigation.

loans.name: Chan's Group

texts.en:
Chan, 44, is married and lives with her family in a village of the Tbaung Khmum district. She has three children. To make a living, she has been farming rice on one hectare of farmland for several years, and the current business earns her family about 20,000 KHR (Cambodian riels) per day.

There are three members in Chan’s group, and she is a second-loan-cycle client with VisionFund. Now she is leading her group to request a loan to buy fertilizers, and she will use a portion of it to spend on labor costs. She hopes to increase her family’s income from her current business so as to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her farmland.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Sialuga

texts.en:
Sialuga is a 42-years-old married woman with six children. She makes and sells rice, taro, chow mein, frying chicken and curry in the Vaitele Tai Primary School and in her community to earn a living. She has two years of experience with this business.

Sialuga needs a loan to buy rice, boxes of chicken, vegetables, foam plates, curry powder and Glad wrap. She plans to use her profits to save for family needs. Sialuga has been a member of SPBD since 2010.

loans.use: to buy a bag of rice, boxes of chicken, vegetables, foam plates, curry powder and Glad wrap.

loans.name: Nhoeurm

texts.en:
Nhoeurm is a local citizen residing in Battambang province’s Moung Russey district.  She has four children, and currently, only one kid is still in school. For the sake of her family, she and her husband do rice farming as their main income source; it is the business that she has had for 20 years. 

Nhoeurm is a second-time borrower with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). Her past loan enabled her to support her child to finish secondary school and move  on to pursue a university degree. However, the tuition fee is quite a burden for her family. To tackle this issue, she applied for an education loan to pay the tuition fee of her son, who is studying at a local school specializing in Finance and Banking. Moreover, with a small portion of her loan, she will buy school materials for her son. 

She hopes this loan will support her son’s education costs on time so that her child can pay more attention to his studies.

loans.use: To pay the tuition fee of her son.

loans.name: Hoeurn

texts.en:
Hoeurn is 62 years old and married. She is a resident from Moung Russey district of Battambang province. To strive for a living, she does rice farming on a 10-hectare area as the main source of income. It is the business that she has occupied for 20 years, earning about 40,000 KHR (Cambodian riels) per day.  

This is the first microloan for Hoeurn with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She is seeking 3,000,000 KHR in order to buy fertilizer and insecticide for her crop. She hopes that she can gain a good income from her crop.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and insecticide for her rice crop.

loans.name: Hos' Group

texts.en:
A rural villager from Thmor Koul district of Battambang province, Hos is a rice grower on a 5-hectare area. To assist her in an earning income, her husband works for others for a fee. She has been involved in the current business for 10 years, earning about 33,600 KHR (Cambodian riels) per day. 

This is the first microloan for Hos with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She leads a group of two to get a new loan. As the leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy fertilizer and insecticide for her crop. She hopes that she can make more income from her current business so that she can keep her children in school until the tertiary level.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and insecticide for her crop.

loans.name: Chanthou's Group

texts.en:
A villager from Kampong Cham province’s Tbaung Khmum district, Chanthou is 39 years old and blessed with two children; one is studying in a local school, and the remaining one is helping with household chores. To supplement the family’s income, Chanthou grows rice while her husband is a paid worker. The business that she has had for ages has returned her about 25,000 KHR (Cambodian riels) per day. 

This is the first micro-loan for Chanthou’s group with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). For this loan cycle, she is seeking 1,000,000 KHR while her co-borrower is seeking 200,000 KHR. As leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy fertilizer for her crop. She hopes to gain a good income from her business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her rice crop.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ou Reang Ov district

loans.name: Elona

texts.en:
Elona is 46 years old. She is separated and has two adult children. She lives in Siloy Calamba, Misamis Occidental. Elona engages in a vegetable-vending business. She owns a small vegetable farm, has been in this business for a year now, and earns 5,000 Philippines pesos a month.

She requested a new loan for pesticides and fertilizers. Elona is a CUMI member of Paglaum MPC since three months ago. Elona hopes that she can earn more out of her business and be able to repay her loan successfully.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farm.

loans.name: Raul

texts.en:
Raul is single with no children. Raul is 42 years old and lives in Poblacion 4, Clarin, Philippines.

Raul sells a variety of products to earn a living and has had this business for 20 years. Each month, he earns 10,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) doing this type of work. He has requested a loan for 50,000 PHP to purchase additional goods to sell such as milk, margarines, canned goods, soy sauce, vinegars, facial scrubs, evaps, toothpastes, detergents, bars, etc.

Raul has been a member of PMPC for six months. In the future, Raul hope to save for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase additional goods to sell such as milk, margarines, canned goods, soy sauce, vinegars, facial scrubs, evaps, toothpastes, detergents, bars, etc.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en: Marina is 59 years old and lives in Lupagan, Clarin, Philippines. She is married with one child. Marina has a tailoring shop that offers tailoring services. She has had this business for 30 years. She requested a loan to buy additional tailoring materials such as polyester, sewing machine oil, tailoring tools, tailoring tape measure, woven interlining, etc. Marina has been a member of PMPC for five years. In the future, Marina hopes to save for future emergencies and to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: to buy additional tailoring materials such as polyester, sewing machine oil, tailoring tools, a tailoring tape measuring, woven interlining, etc.

loans.name: Marita

texts.en: Marita is 47 years old and married with three children. She runs a small business selling barbecue in her community and has been doing this for two years. Marita has requested a loan to buy a barbecue set, soy sauce, garlic, onion, boxes of chicken, sausages, mutton flaps, foam plates and tomato sauce. She joined SPBD in 2011 to gain access to capital. With her earnings, Marita will save for family needs.

loans.use: to buy a barbecue set, soy sauce, garlic, onion, boxes of chicken, sausages, mutton flaps, foam plates and tomato sauce.

loans.name: Las Artesanas Del Fresno Group

texts.es: El grupo "Artesanas del Fresno" está compuesto por sies integrantes, todas son muy buenas vecinas, se conocen muy bien y viven en una comunidad mazahua la cual se caracteriza por que la mayoría de las personas se dedican a la elaboración de sus bordados. Además, en la comunidad existen árboles muy frondosos, los habitantes de la comunidad son muy arraigados a sus costumbres y tradiciones, una característica más de laspersonas de esta comunidad es que aún conservan su lengua mazahua y la siguen hablando además del español. La mayoría de las integrantes del grupo se dedica a la elaboración de bordados conservando la tradición de la comunidad, por eso mismo decidieron ponerle ese nombre a su grupo. Doña Alejandra es una integrante del grupo platica que tiene 52 años de edad está casada desde hace 29 años con el señor Marcos y juntos formaron una familia con cuatro hijos que ahora ya son independientes. Doña Alejandra se dedica a la elaboración de bordados desde hace cuarenta años y cuenta que aprendió la actividad porque desde muy chica su mamá también se dedicaba a la elaboración de estas artesanías. Doña Alejandra argumentó “Saber bordar es toda una tradición, aquí quien no elabora estos tipos de bordados es como si no viviera en la comunidad porque es parte de nuestras costumbres”. La señora Alejandra tiene un local en su casa donde pone a la venta sus artesanías para ella no hay ningún problema para realizarlos. Esta vez está solicitando el crédito para comprara materia prima como agujas, estambres, tela de lana, etc. “Para mí, el crédito será de gran ayuda porque así podre adquirir más fácilmente mis materiales”. El reto de Doña Alejandra es la falta de mercado para poder ofrecer sus artesanías, en su comunidad y sus alrededores es muy difícil obtener buenas ganancias. “Me gustaría que nos ayudaran a buscar un buen mercado o algún medio para ofrecer nuestros bordados”. Ella lleva ya varios meses solicitando crédito a VisionFund y KIVA el cual le ha sido de gran ayuda para su negocio porque con facilidad puede adquirir su materia prima. La meta de Doña Alejandra y las integrantes del grupo es mejorar la calidad de vida de sus familias y se esfuerzan mucho para obtener las mejores ganancias para solventar los gastos de su hogar como la educación de sus hijos, para comprarle ropa, zapatos y mas alimentos. Así como Doña Angélica y las integrantes del grupo están muy agradecidas por el crédito porque podrán invertir sus actividades Doña Ángeles invertirá en la venta de sus cosméticos, Doña Angelina, Zenaida, Lucia, Luisa invertirán en sus bordados Ellas están muy agradecidas con KIVA y Vision Fund por todos sus créditos para ellas ha sido de gran ayuda.
texts.en:
The group “Artesanas del Fresno” (Ash Tree Artisans) is made up of six members. They are all very good neighbors who know each other very well and live in a Mazuhua community, which is recognized for the majority of its people who work making embroidery. In addition, there are very leafy trees in the community. 

The community members have deeply rooted customs and traditions. One main characteristic of the people in this community is that they still speak their Mazahua language, in addition to speaking Spanish. They majority of the group members work making embroidery, preserving the community’s tradition – thus, the name of the group. 

Alejandra is a member of this group. She says that she is 52 years old. She married Marcos when she was 29 years old, and together they have a family of four children who are now independent. Alejandra has worked doing embroidery since she was forty. She says that she learned this work because, since she was very young, her mother also worked making these handicrafts. 

Alejandra concluded that, “Knowing how to embroider is a tradition; here, anyone who doesn’t make these kinds of embroidery - it’s as if they didn’t live in the community, because it’s part of our customs.”

Alejandra has a small shop in her house where she sells her handicrafts. She has no problem making sales. This time, she is requesting the loan to purchase more material, like needles, yarn, wool cloth, etc. 

“For me, the loan will be a great help, because in this way I will be able to obtain my material more easily.”

Alejandra’s main obstacle is the lack of a market in which to offer her goods; in her community and the surrounding areas, it’s very difficult to get good earnings. 

“I would like it if they would help us to look for a good market or some method of offering our embroidery.”

She has been taking out loans from VisionFund and Kiva for several months, which has been a great help for her business because of the ease with which she can obtain her raw material. Alejandra’s and the group’s goal is to improve the quality of life for their families. They make a great effort to obtain better earnings to pay for their home expenses, like their children’s education and buying more clothing, shoes and food for them. 

Likewise, Angélica and the other group members are very grateful for the loan, because they will be able to invest in their businesses. Ángeles will invest in her cosmetics sales, and Angelina, Zenaida, Lucia, and Luisa will invest in their embroidery. They are very grateful to Kiva and VisionFund for all of their loans; for them, it has been a big help.

loans.use: to purchase raw material like fabric, needles, and yarn.

loans.name: Faauliuli

texts.en: Faauliuli is a 39-year-old single lady with two children. She would like to start a small business in Elei (printed fabric designs). In order to do this, Faauliuu needs a loan to buy stencils, fabric color paints, brushes, materials and elei carved design board. She hopes to use her profits to save for her kids' education. She became a member of SPBD in 2013.

loans.use: to buy stencils, fabric color paints, brushes, materials and an elei (printed fabric designs) carved design board.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria is 32 years old and married with 2 children.  She owns and operates a business venture: sewing. She has 3 years of experience in this line of business.  Maria needs a loan to buy thread, sets of rolls of material, an overlocker machine and dozens of buttons. She hopes to use her profits to improve her business and help her family. She joined SPBD in 2010.

loans.use: to buy thread, sets of rolls of material, an overlocker machine and dozens of buttons

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia is 56 years old and married with three children. Alicia works very hard to provide for them.

Alicia runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock like canned goods, seasonings, soft-drinks, sugar, noodles, etc. to sell in her general store.

Alicia has been in this business for 15 years and sells a variety of items such as canned goods, seasonings, soft-drinks, sugar, noodles, etc. 

Alicia would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional stock like canned goods, seasoning, soft-drinks, sugar, noodles, etc. to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Ma. Babylyn

texts.en:
Ma. Babylyn is a married woman with two children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Ma. Babylyn is 40 years old and has two children who are in school.

Ma. Babylyn has a general store business in the Philippines. Ma. Babylyn requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase more items to sell in her general store.

Ma. Babylyn has been in this business for 16 years. In the future, Ma. Babylyn would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Dina works hard to support her family. Dina is married and has a gasoline retail business in the Philippines.

Dina requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional containers of gasoline to sell.

Dina has been in this business for 1 year now.

Dina would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional containers of gasoline to sell.

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena is 76 years old and married with one child. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Magdalena has a business buying and selling bananas in the Philippines. Magdalena requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase more bananas to sell in her fruit stall.

Magdalena has been in this business for 16 years. Magdalena would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more bananas to sell in her stall.

loans.name: Minerva

texts.en:
Minerva is 38 years old, is married and has two children who are in school.

Minerva is in the agricultural business of pig fattening in the Philippines. Minerva requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vaccines for her pigs.

Minerva has been in the pig fattening business for 1 year now, and has borrowed 4 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

Minerva would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vaccines for her pigs.

loans.name: Nelgie

texts.en:
Nelgie is 52 years old and married with three children. Nelgie works very hard to provide for them.

Nelgie runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 26000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stocks to sell like canned goods, eggs, milk, coffee, snack foods, and other groceries in her general store.

Nelgie has been in this business for 12 years and sells a variety of items such as canned goods, eggs, milk, coffee, snack foods, and other groceries. 

In the future, Nelgie would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks to sell like canned goods, eggs, milk, coffee, snack foods, and other groceries in her general store

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita works hard to support her family. Teresita is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Teresita requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more items like seasonings, shampoo, hair conditioners, detergent soap, noodles, etc. to sell in her general store.

Teresita has been in this business for 12 years now.

Teresita would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more items like seasonings, shampoo, hair conditioners, detergent soap, noodles, etc. to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Orbelina Del Carmen

texts.es: Orbelina de 48 años de edad se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza y productos para el hogar, posee mucha clientela por la calidad y buenos recios de sus productos vende en su  lugar de residencia y también de forma ambulante por las diferentes colonias que se encuentran cerca de su lugar de residencia, con lo que obtiene de su trabajo logra solventar algunos gastos de su hogar, vive en casa propia con su esposo y sus dos hijos de 18 y 16 años de edad ellos estudian actualmente, doña Orbelina esta solicitando un préstamo para la compra de mas mercadería por mayor para seguir con su negocio y darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: 48 year old Orbelina sells beauty products and household goods. She has many customers because of the quality and good prices of the products that she sells from her home and also by traveling to the different villages near to where she lives. With what she makes from her work, she is able to cover some of the household expenses. She lives in her own house along with her husband and their two children who are 18 and 16 years old and currently in school. Oberlina is requesting a loan to buy more wholesale merchandise so she can continue her business and give her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy beauty products: lotions, creams, etc and household goods: soaps, detergents, etc.

loans.name: Sophorn

texts.en:
A married mother of four children, Sophorn is 47 years old and a resident in the Kandal Province, Sa Ang district. Sophorn makes a living through selling grocery items in the village.  Engaging in this business for 29 years, she is able to earn about 25,000KHR per day to meet the family’s needs. 
Sophorn is just with the VisionFund this cycle. 

Now she is asking for the education loan to pay for her son’s tuition fee at University, specializing in Law. She hopes that her son will have special skills for a long term income which will support the family.

loans.use: To pay for her son’s tuition fee at university

loans.name: Perla Elizabeth

texts.es: La Señora Perla habita Zona llamada Veracruz, a sus 28 años de edad es madre soltera de una hija, quien asiste al colegio de promaria, la actividad comercial de Perla es la venta de Ropa Usada, y quiere introducir en su mercaderia ropa nueva para niños que es lo que ella considera que mas vende. Solicita el crédito para compra Paca de Ropa. Con esta inversión su hija obtendrá mejores condiciones de vida ya que su negocio es muy rentable ella vende ambulante y en su casa pero la mayoria de sus clientes trabajan con ella por encargo. gracias a Kiva y Afodenic perla y su hija viven mejor y sus ingresos son muy buenos.
texts.en: Perla lives in the Veracruz area. She is 28 years old and a single mother of one daughter who goes to elementary school. Perla's business is selling second hand clothing and she wants to add more children's clothing to her range as this is what she thinks she sells most of. She is requesting a loan to buy a bale of clothes. With this investment her daughter will have better living conditions as the business is very profitable. She sells by traveling and also from her house. Thanks to Kiva and Afodenic, Perla and her daughter live better and their profits are very good.

loans.use: to buy a bale of second hand clothing.

loans.name: Deap's Group

texts.en: Deap is a resident from the Kampong Cham province. She is 43 years old and a married mother of three children. Her main source of income is from one hectare of rice farming. To supplement the family’s income, her husband works for others for a fee. Deap has occupied herself with her current business for several years, earning about 16,700 KHR per day. This is the original loan for Deap with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner).  She and her co-borrower are seeking for the same loan amount of 1,000,000 KHR each. As the leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy fertilizer for her crop and to pay for labor costs. She hopes that she can gain a good income from her agri-business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her crop and to pay for labor costs.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ou Reang Ov district

loans.name: Sambath

texts.en: Sambath is 65 years old and a resident from the Sa Ang district of Kandal province. She is a mother of four children, two of whom are university students. For the sake of her family, she manages a one-and-a-half hectare area for planting mangoes and growing fish for additional income. This is not her first loan for VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She has repaid her past two loans wisely to support her business in a timely  manner and keep her children in school. Now, she is in need of capital to support her son who wants to pursue a Bachelor's degree specializing in English Literature. Therefore, she is seeking for a new loan as a third-time borrower to cover her son’s education costs. She hopes her son can pay more attention to his studies and get a good grade.

loans.use: To cover her son’s education cost

loans.name: Suyapa

texts.es:
Suyapa es una joven de 26 años emprendedora y luchadora la cual cada día se levanta temprano por la mañana para atender a su esposo y sus 2 hijos los cuales están en la escuela en diferentes grados de educación. Posteriormente ella y su esposo se trasladan hasta sus cultivos de  fresa para poder asistirlos y darles mantenimiento aplicando abono, fertilizantes, manzate, urea entre otros que son de gran ayuda para mantener sus cultivos sanos y limpios de plagas. A pesar de no tener experiencia educativa por la falta de apoyo económico por sus padres ella tiene mucha experiencia en sus cultivos de fresa las cuales atiende desde muy temprana edad ya que sus padres la apoyaron enseñándole todo lo necesariamente posible en el trabajo de campo para que ella con el tiempo cultivara sus propias tierra y generara ingresos para el sustento de su familia y hogar. Sus cultivos de fresas están ubicados a un kilómetro de distancia al cual se trasladan a pie diariamente.

Sus sueños y planes a futuro son los de poder comprar más tierra para seguir cultivando fresas las cuales son de muy buena calidad y muy buen tamaño para posteriormente ser vendidas en el mercado local y nacional. Como madre apoyar a sus hijos en sus estudios, guiarlos por el buen camino y dando las oportunidades a ellos que ella en su juventud no tubo. Por lo que hoy en día solicita un financiamiento para la compra de insumos agrícolas para dar mantenimiento a sus cultivos de fresas.
texts.en:
Suyapa is a young woman aged 26, she is hard-working and gets up early every morning to care for her husband and their two children who go to school in different grades. After that, she and her husband go to their strawberry cultivations in order to maintain them with manure, fertilizers, fungicide, urea, etc. This keeps the cultivations healthy and free from plagues. 

Although she hasn't studied since her parents weren't able to support her economically, she has gained a lot of experience from her strawberry cultivations, which she has cared for since an early age. Her parents supported her, teaching her all they could about the work in the fields so that with time she would be able to cultivate her own land and generate an income for her family and her household. Their strawberry cultivations are located 1 km away and they go there by foot every day.

Her dreams and plans for the future are to be able to buy more land in order to continue cultivating strawberries of good quality and good size, which she will sell on the local and national markets, as well as to support her children in their studies, guide them in the right direction, and give them the opportunities that she didn't have when she was young. This is why she is applying for a loan so that she can buy agricultural inputs to maintain her strawberry cultivations.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs to maintain her strawberry cultivations

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Catherine is a Kiva borrower. She describes herself as a go-getter and never misses opportunities. She operates a farm  where she grows crops and also does business to earn extra income. She describes her biggest challenge to be a lack of water connection items to do irrigation. She will use the KES 5,000 loan to buy water pipes for irrigating her farm. She hopes that in the future, she will maximize productivity of the farm by improving her income. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM. The previous loan of KES 10,000 was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy water pipes

loans.name: Sambo

texts.en: Sambo is 30 years old and a resident of Kandal province. She is a single lady who strives for a living via working at a local company. This is the occupation that she has had for two years. This is the first microloan for Sambo with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner) as she wants to pursue her Bachelor's degree specializing in Business Management. She hopes that this loan will enable her to obtain an academic degree and get a better job with a good income to support her family.

loans.use: To pursue her Bachelor's degree specializing in Business Management

loans.name: Corsina

texts.en:
Corsina is 48 years old and single with three children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Corsina is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Corsina has been raising pigs for 12 years and also earns additional income from abaca weaving.

She is working tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Sony

texts.en:
Sony, 34, is married with three children residing in a rural village located in the Kandal province’s Kandal Stoeng district, Cambodia. She has three children, one of whom is in school. For the last ten years, she has been farming rice, planting vegetables, and sometimes working as a tailor to supplement her income.

This is Sony’s first loan with VisionFund. She is now requesting a loan of 2,000,000 KHR to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her land and to use a portion of it to buy cows to raise. She hopes to increase her income from her current business in order to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her cultivated land.

loans.name: Maria Del Carmen

texts.es: Maria de 44 años de edad se dedica desde hace 13 años a la crianza de ganado de engorde, posee mucha clientela ya establecida que la prefieren  por la calidad de su producto y los buenos precios,  con lo que gana de sus ventas logra solventar algunos gastos de su hogar, vive en casa propia con su esposo y sus cuatro hijos de 24, 22, 19 y 18 años de edad ellos estudian actualmente, doña Maria esta solicitando un préstamo para la compra de otra vaca de engorde y así seguir con su trabajo para obtener mejores ganancias y darle a su familia una mejor estabilidad económica.
texts.en: María is 44 years old and, for the last 13 years, she has been raising and fattening-up cattle.  She has many established customers who prefer to come to María because of the quality of her products and the good prices.  With profits from her sales, María is able to cover some household costs.  She lives in her own house with her husband and four children, who are 24, 22, 19, and 18 years old respectively.  They are all studying.  María is applying for a loan to buy another cow to fatten up and thus continue with her work so as to earn higher profits and to give her family more financial stability.

loans.use: to buy another cow to fatten up.

loans.name: Alba Del Carmen

texts.es: Alba de 31 años de edad es madre soltera vive en casa propia con su hijo de 8 años de edad, ella se dedica a la elaboración y venta de tamales en su lugar de residencia, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas logra solventar algunos gastos de su hogar, posee mucha clientela que la prefieren por su amabilidad a la hora de vender, alba está solicitando un crédito para la compra de maíz, pollos, verduras, tomates, especias, etc. que son los ingredientes necesarios para la elaborar los tamales y así poder seguir con su negocio ya que esa es su única fuente de ingresos  y así darle a su hijo una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Alba is 31 years old and a single mother.  She lives in her own house with her eight-year-old son.  Alba makes a living preparing and selling "tamales" (a corn-based dish) from her home.  With her profits, she is able to cover some household costs.  Alba has many customers who come to her because of the friendly service she offers. Alba is applying for a loan to buy corn, chicken, vegetables, tomatoes, spices, and other items.  These are the ingredients she needs to make the "tamales".  With the loan Alba can continue with her business - her only source of income - and give her son a better quality of living.

loans.use: to buy corn, chicken, vegetables, tomatoes, spices, and more.

loans.name: Hugo Roberto

texts.es: Hugo de 48 años de edad es el propietario de una tienda de víveres, en el municipio donde habita con su cónyuge y sus dos hijos de 11 a 14 años. Hace 20 años inició un pequeño negocio el cual fue ampliando luego arrendó un local en otro barrio donde le fue muy bien y aun así debió entregarlo a sus dueños, pues estos lo necesitaban. Decidido a continuar ubicó el negocio en su propia casa donde ha logrado mejorarlo poco a poco en relación con sus ventas, las cuales hace de contado y en la medida que lo requiera la población objeto.  Su meta mas adelante es ampliar su negocio adecuar su vivienda y apoyar el estudio de sus hijos, su mayor desafío ha sido el cambio de instalaciones, pero poco a poco con un buen servicio ha logrado incrementar su clientela. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará víveres como arroz, aceite, cereales, lácteos enlatados etc. Con esta inversión tendrá un mejor inventario y sus ventas aumentarán y es que esto es justamente lo que hace exitoso un credikiva.
texts.en: Forty-eight-year-old Hugo is the owner of a general store in the town where he lives with his partner and two children, who are aged 11 and 14 years old.  Twenty years ago Hugo started a small business, which later grew.  He rented premises in another barrio where things went very well but he had to leave the premises as the owners needed them again.  Having decided to continue with the business, he relocated to his own house, where, little by little, sales have improved.  Sales are on credit, according to customers' needs.  Hugo's future goal is to expand his business, adapt his home for the shop, and support his children's studies.  His biggest challenge has been changing premises but, little by little, with good service, Hugo has managed to increase his number of customers.  Hugo is currently applying for a Kiva loan, his first with the "Fundación Mario Santo Domingo".  He will use the loan to buy supplies such as rice, oil, cereals, tinned products, and dairy products.  This loan will give Hugo better inventory and his sales will increase.  And with such results, his Kiva loan will have been a success.

loans.use: to buy supplies such as rice, oil, cereals, tinned products, and dairy products.

loans.name: Hoern

texts.en:
Hoern is 53 years old and married. He lives in a rural village of the Battambang province’s Thmor Koul district where he earns a living by farming rice and also working as a motor-taxi driver. Together, Hoern and his wife can earn about US $10 per day from their current business and can save about US $6 each day for their future needs.

This is Hoern’s first loan with Kiva’s partner VisionFund. He is applying for a loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides for his farmland. He hopes to produce more rice and sell it for a good price in order to earn a better living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticides for his farmland

loans.name: Sokheang

texts.en:
Sokheang is 25 years old and married with one daughter. She is a villager from a rural area located in Battambang province’s Thmor Koul district. She and her husband earn a living by farming rice and raising pigs. 

This is Sokheang's third loan with VisionFund, and she successfully repaid her previous loans. The loans from VisionFund have helped her to better support her family. She is now asking for a loan of 2,500,000 KHR to buy feeds to nourish her pigs. She will also use a portion of the loan to buy fertilizer for her paddy rice. She hopes to raise her pigs to be fat and healthy so she can sell them for a good price and to grow her rice in a timely fashion in order to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy pig feeds and fertilizers for her rice paddy

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en:
Esterlita is a hardworking entrepreneur who raises chickens in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 4 years, and she earns additional income from buying and selling bamboo.

Esterlita successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business. She is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase feeds and other supplies for her chickens. 

Esterlita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money to be able to afford to send her children to school in the future.

loans.use: to purchase feeds and other supplies for her chickens

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en: Gabriel is a 35-year-old married man. He describes himself as respectful and obedient. He operates a business in which he transports customers using his motorcycle. He describes his biggest challenge as a lack of water storage facilities. Gabriel will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy a water storage facility to store clean water for domestic use. In the future, he hopes to buy another motorcycle. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy a water storage facility

loans.name: Thanapati Self Help Group

texts.en:
Sukanti is a 47-year-old lady living with her husband and her son, aged 21 years, who is studying in college. She has two cows and sells milk in her village. Her husband is a farmer who helps Sukanti in her business. Sukanti's monthly income is very low. That is why she is unable to give more money to her son to get admitted to a good college. 

Sukanti has formed a group that is called Thanapati Self Help group (SHG). All the members of this group are women engaged in different kinds of activities, like milk selling, vegetable selling, flower selling, etc. All the members of this group are very cooperative with each other.

Sukanti, along with her group, has requested a loan amount of 117,000 INR (Indian rupees) for purchasing a cow and fodder. She has a dream to educate her son and give a better standard of life to her family.

loans.use: to purchase a cow and fodder.

loans.name: Choern

texts.en:
Choern, 33, lives in a rural village of Battambang province’s Bovel district. She is a married mother of two children, both of whom are dependents and still in school. Her family’s income comes from farming on a leased rice paddy. Choern has been in this business for seven years. Currently, she can earn about KHR 33,000 per day and manages to save about KHR 17,000 per day for their future needs. 

Choern has been a member of VisionFund for three cycles already and she completely repaid the previous loans. She successfully used her loans from VisionFund to better support her living. She is applying for another loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland. With this loan, she hopes to extend her farmland to increase her business and thereby earn more income.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland

loans.name: Georgeanne

texts.en:
Georgeanne is 44 years old and married with three children. She runs a general store in the Philippines and works hard to provide for her family.

Georgeanne has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional goods, such as soft drinks, rice, vinegar, soy sauce, noodles, and other items, to sell in her store.

Georgeanne has borrowed and repaid 3 previous loans from NWTF. She has been running the general store for 15 years and also earns additional income from pig fattening.

Georgeanne aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional goods to sell

loans.name: Lalin's Group

texts.en:
Lalin is 38 years old and married with two children, both of whom are dependents and still in school. She lives in a wooden house with her family members in a rural village of the Sangke district. To make a living, Lalin sells grocery items while her husband works as an electrician. Having been in this business for four years, Lalin manages to earn about 65,000 KHR per day and can save about 15,000 KHR each day for their future needs.

This Lalin's first loan with VisionFund. She is leading a three-member group to apply for a loan. Lalin will use her portion of the loan to buy more grocery items for resale. She hopes to earn more income from her current business in order to earn a better living.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items for resale

loans.name: Sey's Group

texts.en:
A 43-year-old widow residing in a rural village of Battambang province’s Thmor Koul district, Sey has eight children, five of whom are dependents and still in school. She earns a living by farming rice. Having been in this business for ten years, she can earn about KHR 35,000 per day and can save about KHR 15,000 each day for their future needs. 

Sey has been with VisionFund for seven cycles already and she successfully used her previous loans to better her living conditions. Now she is leading her two-person group to apply for a loan. Sey will use her portion to buy fertilizers for her farmland. She hopes to produce more cassava in order to increase her family’s income and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her farmland

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah is 44 years old and married with four children, two of whom are still in school.

Leah works in agriculture, operating a pig fattening business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase feeds and vitamins for her pigs. Leah has been in pig fattening for 5 years now, and she has borrowed 8 previous loans from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Leah would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase feeds and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Ramona Eulalia

texts.en:
Ramona is 47 years old and has spent most of her life stocking shelves in a supermarket. She was approached by a loan officer from Banco D-MIRO to see if she was interested in a loan. She had never given a thought about starting her own business. 

She decided to apply for a loan and to sell disinfectants from her home. She sells products in bulk, such as Clorox, detergent, etc. Her son helps her with the business by delivering the products. Word-of-mouth is spreading about her business, and her clientele is increasing. 

She hopes to stop working at the supermarket and focus on her growing business.

loans.use: to purchase more cleaning products to sell.

loans.name: Juan Alberto

texts.en:
Juan dreams of becoming an accountant. He was accepted into the Universidad Autónoma Juan Misael Saracho, and now with the chance to achieve his dream, is concerned about affording his schooling. He plans on graduating in June 2015, but without a loan from Vittana, he fears that he will need to defer his graduation. 

With this loan, Juan plans to buy his school books. Up until now, he has been managing to get by without them, but it has become a challenge. With books and school supplies, he feels he will be able to get better grades. 

Juan's parents were never able to complete their primary education. For his family of six, finances have always been tight. With two older siblings attending college already, Juan is unsure how he will be able to finance his education on his own without the assistance of a Vittana loan.

loans.use: to pay for textbooks.

loans.name: Sengly

texts.en:
Originally from a rural village of Kampong Cham province’s Ou Reang Ov district, Sengly is 59 years old and married with three children. She farms rice and plants cassava in order to feed and support her family members. Having been in this business for almost forty years, she is able to earn about KHR 70,000 per day and manages to save about KHR 20,000 each day for their future needs. 

Sengly is in her second loan cycle with VisionFund, and she completely paid back the previous loan. She used the loans wisely and her standard of living gradually improved. Now she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland. She hopes to earn more income from her agribusiness in order to earn more income and further improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ou Reang Ov district

loans.name: Lita

texts.en:
Lita is a 55-year-old married woman with five children who are still in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Lita has had a retail charcoal business in the Philippines for the past four years. She requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell to her customers.

In the future, Lita would like to save enough money that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell to her customers

loans.name: Samson

texts.en: Samson is a Kiva borrower who describes himself as determined. He operates a business in which he transports customers from one place to another on his motorcycle. He describes his biggest challenge as insufficient water storage facilities. He will use the KES 10,000 loan to buy equipment to store clean water for domestic use. He hopes that, in the future, he will grow financially. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy a water storage facility

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for textbooks.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna works hard to support her family. She is married and has an abaca (banana fiber) weaving business in the Philippines. Lorna has been in this business for 5 years.

Lorna has requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional raw materials for her business. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Virgilia

texts.en:
Virgilia is 43 years old and married with three children.

Virgilia runs a general store in the Philippines and she works hard to provide for her family. She has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stocks to sell, such as canned goods, soft drinks, soy sauce, laundry soap, and shampoo.

Virgilia has borrowed and repaid 3 previous loans from NWTF. She has been running the general store for 19 years and also earns additional income from pig fattening.

Virgilia aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more stocks to sell in her general store

loans.name: Rogers

texts.en:
Rogers is a 38-year-old married man with four children. He has a small retail shop that he started in a rural trading center. But because he has limited capital, he has only a handful of items in the shop.  So, he supplements this work by selling a local brew, which he also makes himself from his own banana plantation. Rogers has about 3.5 acres of land for his banana plantation.  He has been doing this work since 2008. Making local brew has helped him acquire other pieces of land and he has now planted coffee as another source of income. 

Rogers would like a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to help him buy a piece of land to plant more bananas for his local brew.  He is challenged by weather and some competition in his area of operation. Rogers's dream is to see himself construct a recognizable home.

loans.use: To buy a piece of land

loans.name: Ma. Gina

texts.en:
Ma. Gina is married and has a food vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for seven years now. Ma. Gina works hard to support her family. 

Ma. Gina requested a PHP 22,000 loan through NWTF to purchase ingredients for her food production business. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Resurreccion

texts.en:
Resurreccion is 48 years old and married with two children.

Resurreccion works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more groceries and items like canned goods, detergent soap, cooking oil, shampoo and fabric conditioners to sell.

Resurreccion has borrowed and paid back 4 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns additional income from food vending.

Resurreccion aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more groceries and items to sell

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian is 30 years old and single. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Vivian has been raising pigs for 2 years and also earns additional income from a general store.

Vivian is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase feeds, vitamins, vaccines, and other supplies for her pigs. She is working tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business in order to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase feeds, vitamins, vaccines, and other supplies for her pigs

loans.name: Claudia

texts.en:
Claudia is a hardworking entrepreneur who raises pigs in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 20 years and earns additional income from a general store.

Claudia has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs. She dreams of saving enough money that she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Hermenia

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Hermenia works hard to support her family. She has a pig fattening business in the Philippines, and she also earns additional income from a general store. Hermenia is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to purchase feeds and vaccines for her pigs.

Hermenia has been sustaining her business activities through her 4 previous loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her to attain her dream of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase feeds and vaccines for her pigs

loans.name: Tahrir

texts.en:
Tahrir is a conservative person who prefers not to have her photo published online, so her husband appears in the photo. 

Tahrir is a 40 year old married woman from Jabalia. She is a mather to two sons and two daughters. Tahrir's husband works on selling local popular food on a cart in the city. He has been selling food for four years. It is a profitable business and he has his own local customers who buy from him very often, but the business needs some improvement. 

Tahrir requested a USD 2,000 loan from FATEN. This loan will help her husband to buy a small refrigerator to keep extra food to sell in the market. This will increase his daily income.

loans.use: to buy a small refrigerator

loans.name: Ma. Sonora

texts.en:
Ma. Sonora is 38 years old and married with five children. She earns a living through her pig fattening business in the Philippines. Ma. Sonora has been in pig fattening for 16 years and also earns additional income from a general store and selling purified drinking water.

Ma. Sonora is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs. She is working tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is 60 years old and widowed with one child. She has a frozen foods vending business in the Philippines. Marilyn has been in this business for three years. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Marilyn requested a PHP 11,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase more packs of frozen foods to sell. She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more packs of frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn is married and has a general store business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for two years now. Marlyn works hard to support her family. 

Marlyn requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell in her general store. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en:
Salamatu is 48 years old and married with 2 children between the ages  of 13 and 27. She runs a domestic products business in Tombo Western, a rural area in Sierra Leone.

She has been in this business since 2007 and sells sets of pans and different types of food containers within her community. She says that the main problem for her business is that sometimes purchasing power is very low. 

Salamatu requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more spoons and a variety of food containers for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and have a permanent business location. In the future, she would like to open a big shop. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more spoons and a variety of food containers for resale.

loans.name: Kadiatu

texts.en:
Kadiatu is 40 years old and married with four children between the age of 4 and 15 years. She runs a domestic product retail business in Tombo Western rural area in Sierra Leone.

She's been in this business since 2007 and sells glass cups, knives and food containers in her community.  She says that the main problem in her business is slow sales due to the rainy season.

Kadiatu requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more spoons and a variety of food container to sell. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and take care of her family. In the future, she would like to open a big shop. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more spoons and a variety of food containers to sell

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 45-year-old Nancy from Tombo Western rural area in Freetown. She is married and blessed with three children between the ages of 12 and 27. Two of her children attend school. 

Nancy runs a cookery business at home. She sells cooked food at her house. She began running this business after the war. She works at the business throughout the week, from morning to night. Nancy says that the main challenges to her business are price inflation and insufficient finances to expand her business.

Nancy has requested a loan in order to buy more cooking items like rice, palm oil, and cooking seasonings. The extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her children and increase her business. In the future, she plans to build a house. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more cooking items like rice, palm oil, and cooking seasonings.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.es: Doña Lourdes vive en una comunidad donde la gente habla la lengua mazahua, cuenta que tiene 36 años de edad y por el momento está viviendo en unión libre con el señor Carlos, juntos han formado una familia con sus cuatro hijos que van a la escuela. Doña Lulú, como la conocen mejor en su comunidad, ahora solicitó un crédito para surtir su papelería y su dulcería. Ella está muy agradecida con KIVA y VisionFund por el gran logro que ha tenido en sus negocios. También comenta que su gran alegría es el poder pagar la colegiatura de su hija en una escuela privada en la Ciudad de México. Su hija está estudiando una licenciatura en derecho, otros de sus logros ha sido poder tener ya un empleado quien le ayude en la tienda de abarrotes, mientras Doña Lulú y su esposo se dan abasto para poder atender su pollería, su cocina económica, su dulcería y económica. Todos sus negocios han sido a base de grandes esfuerzos, Doña Lulú y su esposo empiezan a trabajar a las siete de la mañana todos los días a esa hora abren todos sus negocios y cierran a las diez de la noche. Siempre tienen muy buenas ventas y comenta Lulú que solo en vacaciones de las ecuelas las ganancias bajan un poco, pero nada preocupante. Doña Lulú dice no tener dificultades en su negocio “La verdad estoy muy agradecida con la institución porque gracias a todos los préstamos he podido sacar adelante todos nuestros negocios". Comenta que hace poco contrataron a un empleado, pusieron canceles nuevos y rótulos presentables para mejorar la imagen de los negocios. "También estoy muy contenta por la educación de mi hija, ahora está en una escuela de calidad. Ella había abandonado sus estudios por un año porque no teníamos dinero para  solventar sus estudios, hace poco inicio la universidad y trabajaremos muy duro para apoyarla en todo”.
texts.en:
Lourdes lives in a community where the people speak the mazahua language.  She is 36 years old and is in a common law marriage with Carlos.  They have formed a family with their four children who attend school.  Lulu, as she is known in the community, is asking for a loan to stock her paper goods store and candy shop.

She is very grateful to Kiva and VisionFund for the great achievement that she has with her businesses.  She also says that her great happiness is to be able to pay her daughters educational expenses at a private school in Mexico City.  Her daughter is studying law.  Another achievement is being able to have an employee to work in her grocery store, while Lulu and her husband work on her chicken farm, restaurant, and candy shop.

All of her businesses have come through great effort.  Lulu and her husband begin working at 7:00 am every day and all of their businesses close at 10:00 pm.  They always have good sales and Lulu says that profits dip slightly only during school vacation, but nothing to worry about.  Lulu says that she doesn't have any problems with her business. "Actually, I am very grateful to the institution because the loans have helped me get our businesses ahead."

She says that they recently hired an employee, and installed new doors and signs to present a better appearance for her businesses.  "I'm also very happy about my daughter's education.  She is in a good school now.  She had quit school for a year because we didn't have the money to pay her studies.  She recently started in university and we work very hard to support her in everything."

loans.use: to stock her paper goods store and candy shop.

loans.name: Regina Jahaira

texts.es: Regina es una joven de 28 años de edad, activa, trabajadora, madre soltera de una niña menor de edad, Regina labora para una empresa privada como promotora de ventas. Ella habita en una parte de la casa de su madre, solicita este crédito con el fin de continuar con una segunda etapa de la construcción de la vivienda faltándole los últimos detalles como la puesta de verjas y ventanas para poder habitarla por completo, con esta mejora, tendrán más espacio y sobre todo seguridad.
texts.en: Regina, 28, is an active an hard-working single mother. She has one young daughter. Regina works for a private company as a sales promoter. She lives in a part of her mother's house. She is requesting this loan to continue with the second phase of her home construction. She still needs the final details such as a fence door and windows so she can fully live in it. With this improvement, she will have more space and, most importantly, she will be safer.

loans.use: to buy a fence, door, and windows.

loans.name: Ma. Nila

texts.en:
Ma. Nila is 53 years old and married with eight children. With one child still in school, Ma. Nila works very hard to provide for the family.

Ma. Nila runs a general store in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 5 years and sells a variety of items such as snack foods, canned goods, cooking oil, milk, fabric conditioner, and noodles. She has requested a PHP 27,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stocks to sell in her general store.

In the future, Ma. Nila would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks to sell in her general store

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 45-year-old Isatu from Tombo Western, a rural area near Freetown. She is married and blessed with 3 children between the ages of 18 years and 25 years. One of her children is currently going to school. She began this business because she wants to strive to earn her living.

Isatu runs a retail business at home; she sells cooking items like rice, palm oil and cooking season at her house. She has been running this business since the end of the war. She works on the business throughout the week, from morning to night. Isatu says that the main challenge to her business is price inflation and insufficient finance to expand her business.

Isatu has requested a loan in order to buy more cooking items like rice, palm oil and cooking season. The extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and educate her children. In the future, she plans to build a house. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more cooking items for resale

loans.name: Hach

texts.en:
Originally from a rural village of the Stoeng Sen district of Kampong Thom province, Hach is a 60-year-old married mother of three children. Rice farming has been the main source of her family’s income for six years. To better support the family and earn more income, her husband works as a paid construction worker. Together, they can earn about US $17 per day to meet family’s needs and manage to save about US $5. 

This is Hach's fifth loan with Kiva's partner, VisionFund. The previous loans, which she successfully paid back, have helped her to gradually sustain her living conditions as well as her business. She is currently applying for an education loan to pay tuition for her oldest son to learn driving. She sincerely hopes that this loan will enable her son to get his driver's license.

loans.use: to pay tuition for her oldest son to learn driving

loans.name: Leang

texts.en:
Residing in the Stoeung Sen district of Kompong Thom province, Leang is 43 years old and married. She has three children, one of whom is still in school. Leang has struggled to make a living by working as a tailor in the village. She has been engaged in this business for 10 years and is able to earn up to US $8 per day. However, she is able to save only US $3 each day after expenses. 

Leang is applying as a first-time borrower with VisionFund for a loan to pay school fees for her daughter, who studies finance and banking. She hopes that the loan will allow her to keep her daughter in university to pursue her degree so that she will find a good job after graduation.

loans.use: To pay her daughter's school fees

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Isatu is in her early 30s and married with 4 children between the age of 8 years and 12 years. She runs a domestic product business in Tombo Western, a rural area in Sierra Leone.

She has been in this business since she left school and sells sets of pans, wax cotton and different types of food containers within her community.  She says that the main problem for her business is insufficient capital.

Isatu requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more wax cotton, sets of pans and a variety of food containers for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and have a permanent business location. In the future, she would like to open a big shop. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more wax cotton, sets of pans and a variety of food containers for resale.

loans.name: Mariatu

texts.en:
Meet Mariatu, she is a woman in her late 20s from Tombo, in Western Area near Freetown. She is married with two children aged 3 and 10 years old.  After the war, Mariatu established her bread business. She began her business because she needed to create income to support the home. She works at the business 10 hours per day and 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge in her business is transportation problems. 

Mariatu requires a loan in order to buy more flour, sugar and cooking oil to prepare her bread. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and improve her standard of living. In the future, Mariatu plans to change her business to a provision store. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more flour, sugar and cooking oil to prepare her bread.

loans.name: Hassanatu

texts.en:
Hassanatu is 35 years old and married with three children between the age of 2 and 13 years. She runs a general merchandise business in Tombo, Western Rural Area, Sierra Leone. 

She's been in this business since before she got married and sells soda, milk, cigarettes and biscuits in her community.  She says that the main problem in her business is lack of capital to expand her business.

Hassanatu requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more soda, milk, cigarettes and biscuits to sell. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and improve her standard of living. In the future, she would like to expand her business even more. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy purchase more soda, milk, cigarettes and biscuits for resale.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is in her early forties and married with three children between the ages of 8 and 18. She runs a domestic products sales business in Tombo, a western rural area of Sierra Leone.

Fatmata has been in this business since the last rainy season and she sells glass cups, knives, and food containers within her community.  She says that the main problems in her business are transportation and sometimes the products break.

Fatmata requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more spoons and a variety of food containers for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and take care of her family. In the future, she would like to open a big shop. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy more spoons and a variety of food containers for resale.

loans.name: Mariatu

texts.en:
Meet 30-year-old Mariatu from Tombo, a western rural area in Freetown. She is married with one four-year-old child.  After she got married, Mariatu established her domestic products business. She began her business because she needed to earn an income to support her household. She works at the business 10 hours per day and 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is a lack of enough capital to run her business.

Mariatu requires a loan in order to buy a variety of pan sets and plastic and rubber food containers. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and renovate her house. In the future, Mariatu plans to own a big shop. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy a variety of pan sets, and more plastic and rubber food containers.

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Isatu is in her early twenties and is married with two children between the ages of 2 and 4. She runs a general merchandise business in Tombo, a western rural area of Sierra Leone. Isatu began her business to get her daily bread.

Isatu has been in this business since she left school and she sells soda, milk, cigarettes, and biscuits within her community.  She says that the main challenge in her business is the lack of capital to expand.

Isatu requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more soda, milk, cigarettes, and biscuits for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and improve her standard of living. In the future, she would like to open a big provision shop. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more soda, milk, cigarettes, and biscuits for resale.

loans.name: Ramatu

texts.en:
Ramatu is in her late 40s and married with 3 children between the ages of 5 months and 11 years. She runs a domestic product business in Tombo Western, a rural area in Sierra Leone.

She has been in this business since 2007 and sells glass cups, knives and food containers within her community. She says that the main problem for her business is an improper business location.

Ramatu requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more spoons and a variety of food containers for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and take care of her family. In the future, she would like to change her business to palm oil and gari business. She is grateful for your support

loans.use: to purchase more spoons and a variety of food container for resale.

loans.name: Garansiano

texts.en:
Garasiano is a 45-year-old married man with six children; three of his children attend school. He comes from a rural area in Kyezitira Nyarukika, and he makes local brew and farms as his sources of income. He sells his local brew to the villagers. Through his business, he has managed to support his family and pay school fees for his children.

Garasiano wants to borrow UGX 900,000 to buy more plantains, which he will use to make more brews so that he can expand his business. His main challenges are seasonal changes and price fluctuations that affect his business.

loans.use: To buy plantains for making local brews

loans.name: Divina

texts.en:
Divina is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She is 29 years old and has a live-in partner and two children, both of whom are in school.

For two years, Divina has had a retail business, selling ready-to-wear clothing in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stocks of clothing to sell.

In the future, Divina would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of ready-to-wear clothing to sell

loans.name: Kadiatu

texts.en:
Kadiatu is in her late forties and is married with four children. She runs a business selling wood in Tombo, a western rural area in Freetown. She started this business because she wanted to generate a permanent source of income.  

Kadiatu has been in this business since the rebel war and she sells wood at her house.  She describes her major hardships as inadequate funds to run her business and transportation problems.  

Kadiatu requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more wood to expand her business. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and improve her standard of living. In the future, Kadiatu would like to change her business to a food stand. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more wood to expand her business

loans.name: Aminata

texts.en:
Aminata is in her late 40’s. She is widowed with 3 children. She runs a wood business in Tombo, which is in the Western Area Rural District near Freetown. She started this business because she wants to generate a permanent source of income.  

Aminata has been in this business since the death of her husband during the rebel war. She sells wood at her house.  She describes her major hardship as inadequate funds to run her business and transportation problems.  

Aminata requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more wood to expand her business. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and improve her level of living. In the future, she would like to change her business to a food stand store. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more wood to expand her business.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is 48 years old and married with 2 children between the ages of 16 years and 30 years. She runs a palm oil business in Tombo Western, a rural area near Freetown. She started this business because she wants to generate a permanent source of income.  

She has been in this business since 2008 and sells palm oil at her house. She describes her major hardship as inadequate funds to run her business and facing transportation problems.  

Nancy requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more native rice and palm oil to expand her business. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and improve her level of living. In the future, she would like expand her business to a local food store. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more native rice and palm oil to expand her business.

loans.name: Aminata

texts.en:
Aminata is 35 years old and married with one child aged 2 years. She runs a fish business in Tombo Western, a rural area in Sierra Leone. She started this business to meet her daily needs.

She has been in this business since she got married and sells fish within her community. She says that at present her business is doing well because from the profits, she has been able to take care of her family.

Aminata requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more fish for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and repay her loan. In the future, she would like to expand her business to a higher level. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for resale.

loans.name: Gigi

texts.en:
Gigi works hard to support her family. She is married and has had a food vending business in the Philippines for the past five years.

Gigi has requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients like meat, rice, vegetables, and salt for her food production business.

In the future, Gigi would like to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza is 31 years old and married with two children, both of whom are currently in school. She works very hard to provide for the family.

Liza runs a general store in the Philippines, and she has been in this business for 4 years. She has requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stocks like canned goods, cereals, coffee, milk, sugar, bread, and other groceries.

In the future, Liza would like to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of groceries to sell

loans.name: Mabinty

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 47-year-old Mabinty from Tombo Western, a  rural area near Freetown. She is married to a fisherman and blessed with 3 children. Two of her children attend school. 

Mabinty runs a retail business at home; she sells rice, tomato paste and cooking season. She has been running this business for 10 years. She works at the business throughout the week, from morning to night. Mabinty says that the main challenge to her business is price inflation and insufficient finance to expand her business.

Mabinty has requested a loan in order to buy more cooking items like rice, tomato paste and cooking season. The extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her children and increase her business. In the future, she plans to build a house. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more cooking item like rice, tomato paste and cooking season.

loans.name: Rugiatu

texts.en:
Rugiatu is 40 years old and married with 4 children. She runs a fish business in Tombo Western, a rural area in Sierra Leone. She started this business to meet her daily living needs. 

She has been in this business since she got married and sells fish within her community. She says that at present her business is doing well because out of the profit she has been able to take care of her family.

Rugiatu requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more fish for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and have a permanent business location. In the future, she would like to expand her business to a higher level. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for resale.

loans.name: Im's Group

texts.en:
Residing in the Stoeung Sen district of Kompong Thom province, Im is 39 years old and married. She has three children, two of whom are still in school. She has struggled to make a living by farming rice. She has been engaged in this business for 20 years and is able to earn up to KHR 12,000 per day. However, she is able to save only KHR 4,000 each day after expenses. 

Im has just joined VisionFund, and she is leading a group to request her first loan. She will use her portion of the loan to buy materials for constructing a proper latrine. She hopes to have a clean latrine for her family's use with the help of this loan.

loans.use: to buy materials for constructing a proper latrine

loans.name: Mang

texts.en:
A widow with six children who lives in the Kiri Vong District of Takeo Province, Mang plants rice and sells grocery items to provide for her family. With 22 years' experience in these business, she is able to earn up to KHR 13,000 per day to meet the family’s needs. 

Mang is a fifth-time borrower with Kiva’s partner VisionFund. She is now applying for a loan to pay for her daughter’s university tuition. She hopes this loan will enable her to keep her daughter in school until graduation and will also help to relieve the family's financial burden.

loans.use: to pay for her daughter’s university tuition

loans.name: Kadiatu

texts.en:
Meet 30-year-old Kadiatu from Tombo Western, a rural area near Freetown. She is married with 3 children, aged 1 year to 10 years. After the war, Kadiatu established her wood business. She began her business because she needed to create income to support the household. She works at the business 10 hours per day, 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is a transportation problem. 

Kadiatu requires a loan in order to buy more wood for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and improve her standard of living. In the future; Kadiatu plans to change her business to a provision store. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more wood for resale.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is in her early 30s and married with two children between the ages of four and 15 years old. She runs a domestic product business in Tombo, in the western rural area of Sierra Leone.

She has been in this business since 2011. She sells pots and pans and waxed cotton (batik) within her community. She says that her business is doing well because it enables her to take care of her children.

Fatmata has requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more waxed cotton and a variety of food containers for resale. The extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and take care of her family. 

In the future, she would like to open a big shop. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more waxed cotton and a variety of food containers for resale.

loans.name: Gabriela Fatima

texts.en: Gabriela has always dreamt of becoming an environmental engineer. Gabriela was accepted into the Universidad Tecnológica Boliviana and now – with the chance to achieve her dream – is concerned about affording the graduation fee. This fee is often more expensive than the semester's tuition and is a frequent impediment for graduating students in La Paz. She plans on graduating in March 2014, but, without a loan from Vittana, she thinks that she may need to take time off to work and save until she can return to school. Gabriela currently works 40 hours a week and making time to work and go to school has been one of her biggest challenges. With a career in environmental engineering, she expects to earn $59 a day.

loans.use: to pay for her graduation fees

loans.name: Amie

texts.en:
Meet 45-year-old Amie from the Tombo Western rural area in Freetown. She is married with 2 children, ages 10 years and 25 years. One of her children is going to school. After the war, Amie established her clothing business in order to earn income to support her household. She works at the business 10 hours per day, 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is a lack of sufficient capital.
